elements.content: A microporous Pb-based metal–organic framework (MOF) [Pb­(4,4′-ocppy)2]·7H2O (Pb-MOF) has been constructed from 4-(4-carboxyphenyl)­pyridine N-oxide and Pb­(NO3)2. Structural analysis reveals that the Pb-MOF possesses three-dimensional framework with a one-dimensional rhombic channel. When tested as a lithium-ion battery anode, a reversible lithium storage capacity of 489 mAh g–1 was maintained after 500 cycles at 100 mA g–1 as well as excellent cycling stability. The superior electrochemical performance may be derived from the sustenance of the Pb-MOF framework and compositional features of the organic moiety.
elements.clean_text: A microporous Pb-based metal-organic framework (MOF) [Pb(4,4'-ocppy)2]⋅7H2O (Pb-MOF) has been constructed from 4-(4-carboxyphenyl)pyridine N-oxide and Pb(NO3)2. Structural analysis reveals that the Pb-MOF possesses three-dimensional framework with a one-dimensional rhombic channel. When tested as a lithium-ion battery anode, a reversible lithium storage capacity of 489 mAh g-1 was maintained after 500 cycles at 100 mA g-1 as well as excellent cycling stability. The superior electrochemical performance may be derived from the sustenance of the Pb-MOF framework and compositional features of the organic moiety.

elements.content: A porous Pb-MOF with one-dimensional rhombic channels was synthesized under solvothermal conditions. When tested as an anode material for lithium-ion batteries, it exhibited great performances of lithium storage with cycling stability and good rate capability.
elements.clean_text: A porous Pb-MOF with one-dimensional rhombic channels was synthesized under solvothermal conditions. When tested as an anode material for lithium-ion batteries, it exhibited great performances of lithium storage with cycling stability and good rate capability.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), emerging as a new family of functional materials with high porosity, large surface area, and excellent thermal stability and chemical tenability, have been designed and synthesized for environment-, energy-, and medicine-related applications such as gas sorption and separation, heterogeneous catalysis, sensors, luminescence, and so on. Especially, MOFs used as promising electrode materials for lithium storage have been developed dramatically since the Fe-MOF (MIL-53) was first reported as a cathodic material in 2007. For example, Shen and coauthors reported a MOF [Zn­(IM)1.5(abIM)0.5] with remarkable thermal and chemical stability, which exhibited a good Li insertion capacity of 190 mAh g–1 at 100 mA g–1 together with high Coulombic efficiency. More recently, Maiti el al. studied a Mn-BTC MOF with discharge capacity as high as 694 mAh g–1, where the authors demonstrated that the organic moiety played an important role on the mechanism during the charge/discharge process. These studies indicated the potential of MOFs as electrodes in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). However, a novel MOF possessing a high capacity and good rate performance needs to be further developed, especially the stability in organic carbonate electrolytes during cycling and Li insertion/extraction potential for LIB anodes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), emerging as a new family of functional materials with high porosity, large surface area, and excellent thermal stability and chemical tenability, have been designed and synthesized for environment-, energy-, and medicine-related applications such as gas sorption and separation, heterogeneous catalysis, sensors, luminescence, and so on. Especially, MOFs used as promising electrode materials for lithium storage have been developed dramatically since the Fe-MOF (MIL-53) was first reported as a cathodic material in 2007. For example, Shen and coauthors reported a MOF [Zn(IM)1.5(abIM)0.5] with remarkable thermal and chemical stability, which exhibited a good Li insertion capacity of 190 mAh g-1 at 100 mA g-1 together with high Coulombic efficiency. More recently, Maiti el al. studied a Mn-BTC MOF with discharge capacity as high as 694 mAh g-1, where the authors demonstrated that the organic moiety played an important role on the mechanism during the charge/discharge process. These studies indicated the potential of MOFs as electrodes in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). However, a novel MOF possessing a high capacity and good rate performance needs to be further developed, especially the stability in organic carbonate electrolytes during cycling and Li insertion/extraction potential for LIB anodes.

elements.content: On the other hand, lead, a toxic heavy metal, is commonly found due to the widespread applications in paint and battery industries. As one of most poisonous pollutants, Pb­(II) has been considered to be environmentally harmful and a threat to human health because of its long-lasting effect, bioaccumulation, and nonbiodegradation in ecosystems. As a result, some Pb-containing materials are strictly prohibited by some regulations such as waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE) or restriction of hazardous substances (RoHS). However, the Pb­(II) ion possesses unique coordination preferences and a long pair of 6s2 outer electrons, presenting more opportunities for the construction of novel structures with interesting characteristics. Therefore, a deep insight into stereochemistry of Pb-based MOFs would allow a better understanding of the toxicological properties. As a result, some Pb-based MOFs have been reported. Jin and co-workers synthesized a novel three-dimensional (3D) energetic Pb-MOF with unprecedented superior density based on 5,5′-bistetrazole-1,1′-diolate. In the latest report, a porous Pb-MOF based on the rigid V-shaped 4,4′-(pyridine-3,5-diyl)­diisophthalic acid, showing a high CO2 uptake capacity and selectivity, was reported by Yang’s group. Especially in the field of energy storage, Pb, having a low cost, high theoretical capacity of 582 mAh g–1, and a feasible working voltage of 0.5–0.7 V, is often used for automobile lead-acid batteries. Many lead-based compounds and composites as anode materials have been reported, such as P-doping lead oxides, lightweight electrodes, and bare PbO. Therefore, it might be an interesting challenge to develop new lead-based MOFs as potential electrode materials.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, lead, a toxic heavy metal, is commonly found due to the widespread applications in paint and battery industries. As one of most poisonous pollutants, Pb(II) has been considered to be environmentally harmful and a threat to human health because of its long-lasting effect, bioaccumulation, and nonbiodegradation in ecosystems. As a result, some Pb-containing materials are strictly prohibited by some regulations such as waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE) or restriction of hazardous substances (RoHS). However, the Pb(II) ion possesses unique coordination preferences and a long pair of 6s2 outer electrons, presenting more opportunities for the construction of novel structures with interesting characteristics. Therefore, a deep insight into stereochemistry of Pb-based MOFs would allow a better understanding of the toxicological properties. As a result, some Pb-based MOFs have been reported. Jin and co-workers synthesized a novel three-dimensional (3D) energetic Pb-MOF with unprecedented superior density based on 5,5'-bistetrazole-1,1'-diolate. In the latest report, a porous Pb-MOF based on the rigid V-shaped 4,4'-(pyridine-3,5-diyl)diisophthalic acid, showing a high CO2 uptake capacity and selectivity, was reported by Yang's group. Especially in the field of energy storage, Pb, having a low cost, high theoretical capacity of 582 mAh g-1, and a feasible working voltage of 0.5-0.7 V, is often used for automobile lead-acid batteries. Many lead-based compounds and composites as anode materials have been reported, such as P-doping lead oxides, lightweight electrodes, and bare PbO. Therefore, it might be an interesting challenge to develop new lead-based MOFs as potential electrode materials.

elements.content: We have been working on designing and synthesizing porous frameworks connected by functional organic linkers and metal ions and developing their potential application as LIB electrodes. As a continuation of our work, herein, we report the synthesis and crystal structure of a 3D Pb-based MOF, namely [Pb­(4,4′-ocppy)2]·7H2O (4,4′-Hocppy = 4-(4-carboxyphenyl)­pyridine N-oxide), and its electrochemical performance as an anode for LIBs.
elements.clean_text: We have been working on designing and synthesizing porous frameworks connected by functional organic linkers and metal ions and developing their potential application as LIB electrodes. As a continuation of our work, herein, we report the synthesis and crystal structure of a 3D Pb-based MOF, namely [Pb(4,4'-ocppy)2]⋅7H2O (4,4'-Hocppy = 4-(4-carboxyphenyl)pyridine N-oxide), and its electrochemical performance as an anode for LIBs.

elements.content: The organic ligand 4-(4-carboxyphenyl)­pyridine N-oxide (4,4′-Hocppy) was synthesized on the basis of the previously reported method. All available chemicals were commercially obtained and directly used.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

The organic ligand 4-(4-carboxyphenyl)pyridine N-oxide (4,4'-Hocppy) was synthesized on the basis of the previously reported method. All available chemicals were commercially obtained and directly used.

elements.content: Infrared spectra (IR) were carried out in the 4000–400 cm–1 range with a Nicolet FT-IR-170SX infrared spectrometer. A PerkinElmer EA2400 II analyzer was used for elemental analysis. Thermal stability studies were done on a PerkinElmer TGA4000 analyzer. Powder sample was dispensed in porcelain crucible and heated from 30 to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under air flow. A Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) was used to record powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns. The N2 sorption isotherm was measured on Quantachrome Autosorb-1-MP gas sorption analyzer. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken on a JEOL JSM-7001F SEM. Room-temperature NMR experiments were performed with Bruker Avance III 500 MHz NMR spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

Infrared spectra (IR) were carried out in the 4000-400 cm-1 range with a Nicolet FT-IR-170SX infrared spectrometer. A PerkinElmer EA2400 II analyzer was used for elemental analysis. Thermal stability studies were done on a PerkinElmer TGA4000 analyzer. Powder sample was dispensed in porcelain crucible and heated from 30 to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under air flow. A Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) was used to record powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns. The N2 sorption isotherm was measured on Quantachrome Autosorb-1-MP gas sorption analyzer. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken on a JEOL JSM-7001F SEM. Room-temperature NMR experiments were performed with Bruker Avance III 500 MHz NMR spectrometer.

elements.content: A mixture containing 4,4′-Hocppy (11 mg, 0.05 mmol), Pb­(NO3)2 (33 mg, 0.1 mmol), 2 mL of H2O, and 2 mL of dimethylformamide was placed in a glass reaction bottle and heated at 80 °C for 3 d. Then, the system was cooled naturally to obtain colorless rod-like crystals. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3564 (s), 3412 (s), 1637 (m), 1614 (s), 1558 (w), 1382 (w), 1122 (m), 617 (s), 476 (m). Elemental analyses calcd (%) for C24H30N2O13Pb: C, 37.84; H, 3.94; N, 3.67. Found C, 37.81; H, 3.96; N, 3.69.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Pb(4,4'-ocppy)2]⋅7H2O

A mixture containing 4,4'-Hocppy (11 mg, 0.05 mmol), Pb(NO3)2 (33 mg, 0.1 mmol), 2 mL of H2O, and 2 mL of dimethylformamide was placed in a glass reaction bottle and heated at 80 °C for 3 d. Then, the system was cooled naturally to obtain colorless rod-like crystals. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3564 (s), 3412 (s), 1637 (m), 1614 (s), 1558 (w), 1382 (w), 1122 (m), 617 (s), 476 (m). Elemental analyses calcd (%) for C24H30N2O13Pb: C, 37.84; H, 3.94; N, 3.67. Found C, 37.81; H, 3.96; N, 3.69.

elements.content: Prior to the tests, the as-synthesized Pb-MOF samples were heated at 120 °C under vacuum for 2 h. Then the water-free samples were obtained, which were further confirmed by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, vide infra). For electrochemical measurements, the active material (70 wt %), super P carbon black conductive material (20 wt %), and polyvinylidene fluoride (10 wt %) were stirred together with N-methylpyrrolidone as a solvent. The mixture was spread on a copper mesh with a thickness of 10 μm and then dried in vacuum at 70 °C for 18 h. Subsequently, circular disks with a diameter of 12 mm were cut. After that, a coin-type half cell (2025 type) assembly was operated in a glovebox filled with argon; the oxygen and moisture concentrations were below 0.1 ppm. The electrolyte consisted of 1 M LiPF6 in diethyl carbonate (DEC) and ethylene carbonate (EC) (1:1 volume). The cells were galvanostatically cycled between 0.01 and 3.0 V (vs Li/Li+) using a multichannel battery testing system (LAND CT2001A, China). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was carried out at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s–1 on a electrochemical workstation (CHI660C, China). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) at room temperature was also performed using the same instrument with a frequency range from 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Measurement

Prior to the tests, the as-synthesized Pb-MOF samples were heated at 120 °C under vacuum for 2 h. Then the water-free samples were obtained, which were further confirmed by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, vide infra). For electrochemical measurements, the active material (70 wt %), super P carbon black conductive material (20 wt %), and polyvinylidene fluoride (10 wt %) were stirred together with N-methylpyrrolidone as a solvent. The mixture was spread on a copper mesh with a thickness of 10 μm and then dried in vacuum at 70 °C for 18 h. Subsequently, circular disks with a diameter of 12 mm were cut. After that, a coin-type half cell (2025 type) assembly was operated in a glovebox filled with argon; the oxygen and moisture concentrations were below 0.1 ppm. The electrolyte consisted of 1 M LiPF6 in diethyl carbonate (DEC) and ethylene carbonate (EC) (1:1 volume). The cells were galvanostatically cycled between 0.01 and 3.0 V (vs Li/Li+) using a multichannel battery testing system (LAND CT2001A, China). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was carried out at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s-1 on a electrochemical workstation (CHI660C, China). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) at room temperature was also performed using the same instrument with a frequency range from 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz.

elements.content: Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were done using VASP version 5.2.11 with the Vienna ab initio simulation package. Electron–ion interactions were found using the under all-electron PAW (projector augmented wave) approximation. PBE (Perdew, Burke and Enzer) functional was applied to calculate the electronic exchange-correlation energies. The cutoff energy of the plane wave basis set was set to 350 eV. All atoms were relaxed with the convergence to 0.03 eV/Å ions for forces and 10–4 eV/Å for total energy. Fragment BMOF were constructed in a cubic box with a = 20 Å. The Monkhorst–Pack mesh of 2 × 2 × 2 was employed. The binding energy of a Li atom adsorbed on the BMOF fragment is defined as E ab = E Li/Pb‑MOF – E Pb‑MOF – E Li.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Details

Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were done using VASP version 5.2.11 with the Vienna ab initio simulation package. Electron-ion interactions were found using the under all-electron PAW (projector augmented wave) approximation. PBE (Perdew, Burke and Enzer) functional was applied to calculate the electronic exchange-correlation energies. The cutoff energy of the plane wave basis set was set to 350 eV. All atoms were relaxed with the convergence to 0.03 eV/Å ions for forces and 10-4 eV/Å for total energy. Fragment BMOF were constructed in a cubic box with a = 20 Å. The Monkhorst-Pack mesh of 2 × 2 × 2 was employed. The binding energy of a Li atom adsorbed on the BMOF fragment is defined as E ab = E Li/Pb-MOF - E Pb-MOF - E Li.

elements.content: Structure determination was performed on a Bruker APEX II diffractometer using graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Structures were directly solved and refined through the full-matrix least-squares technique on F 2. The solvent molecules were highly disordered and removed by the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON. The relevant crystallographic data are presented in Table S1. Moreover, selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table S2. CCDC 1484501 contains the supplementary crystallographic data.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Structure determination was performed on a Bruker APEX II diffractometer using graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Structures were directly solved and refined through the full-matrix least-squares technique on F 2. The solvent molecules were highly disordered and removed by the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON. The relevant crystallographic data are presented in Table S1. Moreover, selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table S2. CCDC 1484501 contains the supplementary crystallographic data.

elements.content: The as-synthesized Pb-MOF crystal was formulated as [Pb­(4,4′-ocppy)2]·7H2O through single crystal analysis, which was further determined by TGA and EA. Structural analysis reveals that the title Pb-MOF crystallizes in monoclinic C2/c space group and represents a porous framework. Each asymmetric unit contains two ligands, one Pb2+ cation, along with seven lattice water molecules. The Pb ion is seven-coordinated, surrounded by four O atoms from N-oxide and the remaining three oxygen atoms from two carboxylic groups (a). Four oxygen atoms adopting a hemidirected structural arrangement are sitting on one side of the Pb ion, indicative of the existence of an active lone electron pair. Moreover, three weak Pb···O bonds shown as dashed lines (Pb–O3a = 2.804(2), Pb–O4 = 2.819(2), Pb–O6a = 2.864(9) Å) are also presented in a. Two adjacent Pb ions are connected together by two μ2-O atoms of N-oxide, leading to the formation of a 1D Pb–O chain (b). Such coordination interactions generate a 3D framework structure with a size of 9.8 × 9.8 Å2 (c). Through use of the PLATON/SOLV program, a solvent accessible volume was estimated to 40.0% (1265.4 Å3 of the 3165.4 Å3 unit cell volume) after omitting the lattice water molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Description

The as-synthesized Pb-MOF crystal was formulated as [Pb(4,4'-ocppy)2]⋅7H2O through single crystal analysis, which was further determined by TGA and EA. Structural analysis reveals that the title Pb-MOF crystallizes in monoclinic C2/c space group and represents a porous framework. Each asymmetric unit contains two ligands, one Pb2+ cation, along with seven lattice water molecules. The Pb ion is seven-coordinated, surrounded by four O atoms from N-oxide and the remaining three oxygen atoms from two carboxylic groups (a). Four oxygen atoms adopting a hemidirected structural arrangement are sitting on one side of the Pb ion, indicative of the existence of an active lone electron pair. Moreover, three weak Pb⋅⋅⋅O bonds shown as dashed lines (Pb-O3a = 2.804(2), Pb-O4 = 2.819(2), Pb-O6a = 2.864(9) Å) are also presented in a. Two adjacent Pb ions are connected together by two μ2-O atoms of N-oxide, leading to the formation of a 1D Pb-O chain (b). Such coordination interactions generate a 3D framework structure with a size of 9.8 × 9.8 Å2 (c). Through use of the PLATON/SOLV program, a solvent accessible volume was estimated to 40.0% (1265.4 Å3 of the 3165.4 Å3 unit cell volume) after omitting the lattice water molecules.

elements.content: (a) Coordination geometry of Pb2+ ion; (b) [PbO2]∞ chain; (c) 3D framework with the highlighted polyhedra showing the 1D channels along the c-axis.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination geometry of Pb2+ ion; (b) [PbO2]∞ chain; (c) 3D framework with the highlighted polyhedra showing the 1D channels along the c-axis.

elements.content: The as-prepared Pb-MOF was first characterized by IR spectra (Figure S1); the broad peak around 3550–3150 cm–1 corresponded to the vibrations of water molecules. The characteristic peak of −COOH group at around 1700 cm–1 disappeared, indicating the complete deprotonation of Hocppy ligand. Typical absorptions of asymmetric (1652 cm–1) and symmetric (1354 cm–1) vibrations of the carboxyl groups were also observed.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization

The as-prepared Pb-MOF was first characterized by IR spectra (Figure S1); the broad peak around 3550-3150 cm-1 corresponded to the vibrations of water molecules. The characteristic peak of -COOH group at around 1700 cm-1 disappeared, indicating the complete deprotonation of Hocppy ligand. Typical absorptions of asymmetric (1652 cm-1) and symmetric (1354 cm-1) vibrations of the carboxyl groups were also observed.

elements.content: To examine the thermal stabilities of Pb-MOF, PXRD and TGA were applied. PXRD pattern of the as-made product was quite identical to its corresponding simulated results, indicating a pure phase of the bulky crystalline samples (Figure S2). TGA curves in Figure S3 show that the first weight loss between 30 and 150 °C corresponded to the removal of 7 lattice H2O (observed, 16.97%; calcd, 16.54%). Above 300 °C, organic ligands start to decompose, giving PbO as a final product (observed, 29.93%; calcd, 29.30%). To obtain the dehydrated phase, the as-made Pb-MOF was heated at 120 °C for 2 h to remove the solvent molecules. No obvious weight loss of was detected below 300 °C. Subsequently, framework decomposition led to the formation of PbO product (observed, 35.14%; calcd, 35.11%). According to the N2 sorption experiments, the pore characteristics exhibited typical type-I curve with microstructure along with the surface area of 725 m2 g–1 and pore volume of 0.47 cm3 g–1 (Figure S4). Moreover, the Pb-MOF exhibited electrical conductivity of 7.2 × 10–2 S m–1. This relatively high conductivity value and robust framework could provide a charge transport pathway and offer more active sites for embedding Li+.
elements.clean_text: To examine the thermal stabilities of Pb-MOF, PXRD and TGA were applied. PXRD pattern of the as-made product was quite identical to its corresponding simulated results, indicating a pure phase of the bulky crystalline samples (Figure S2). TGA curves in Figure S3 show that the first weight loss between 30 and 150 °C corresponded to the removal of 7 lattice H2O (observed, 16.97%; calcd, 16.54%). Above 300 °C, organic ligands start to decompose, giving PbO as a final product (observed, 29.93%; calcd, 29.30%). To obtain the dehydrated phase, the as-made Pb-MOF was heated at 120 °C for 2 h to remove the solvent molecules. No obvious weight loss of was detected below 300 °C. Subsequently, framework decomposition led to the formation of PbO product (observed, 35.14%; calcd, 35.11%). According to the N2 sorption experiments, the pore characteristics exhibited typical type-I curve with microstructure along with the surface area of 725 m2 g-1 and pore volume of 0.47 cm3 g-1 (Figure S4). Moreover, the Pb-MOF exhibited electrical conductivity of 7.2 × 10-2 S m-1. This relatively high conductivity value and robust framework could provide a charge transport pathway and offer more active sites for embedding Li+.

elements.content: Considering that porous framework structure of Pb-MOF might be advantageous for lithium storage, the electrochemical performances were investigated. a displayed the CV curves of the Pb-MOF electrode. We observed an irreversible process in the electrode material in the first sweep, which could be ascribed to the generation of a SEI layer and decomposition of the electrolyte. From the second scan, a significant decrease in the peak intensity appeared, and the subsequent CV curves showed no clear change, demonstrating good cycling stability and reversibility.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Performance for Lithium Storage

Considering that porous framework structure of Pb-MOF might be advantageous for lithium storage, the electrochemical performances were investigated. a displayed the CV curves of the Pb-MOF electrode. We observed an irreversible process in the electrode material in the first sweep, which could be ascribed to the generation of a SEI layer and decomposition of the electrolyte. From the second scan, a significant decrease in the peak intensity appeared, and the subsequent CV curves showed no clear change, demonstrating good cycling stability and reversibility.

elements.content: Pb-MOF electrode. (a) CV curves. (b) Discharge/charge voltage profiles at 0.1 A g–1. (c) Coulombic efficiency and cycle-life performances at 0.1 A g–1 and 0.5 A g–1, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 2  Pb-MOF electrode. (a) CV curves. (b) Discharge/charge voltage profiles at 0.1 A g-1. (c) Coulombic efficiency and cycle-life performances at 0.1 A g-1 and 0.5 A g-1, respectively.

elements.content: From the galvanostatic charge/discharge voltage profiles in b, we found that most of the discharge voltage was around 0.5 V. The first and second experimental discharge specific capacities are 1522 and 630 mAh g–1, respectively, corresponding to irreversible capacity loss of 58.6%, which could be attributed to the SEI film formation derived from the irreversible lithium ions into the framework and electrolyte decomposition during the initial insertion/desertion process. However, from the consequent cycle, the electrode presented a high and steady specific capacity and still maintained about 489 mAh g–1 with nearly 96% capacity retention after 500 cycles, indicating an excellent cyclic stability.
elements.clean_text: From the galvanostatic charge/discharge voltage profiles in b, we found that most of the discharge voltage was around 0.5 V. The first and second experimental discharge specific capacities are 1522 and 630 mAh g-1, respectively, corresponding to irreversible capacity loss of 58.6%, which could be attributed to the SEI film formation derived from the irreversible lithium ions into the framework and electrolyte decomposition during the initial insertion/desertion process. However, from the consequent cycle, the electrode presented a high and steady specific capacity and still maintained about 489 mAh g-1 with nearly 96% capacity retention after 500 cycles, indicating an excellent cyclic stability.

elements.content: c showed the cycling performance and Coulombic efficiency of the electrode. The initial charge and discharge capacities of 578 and 1522 mAh g–1 were obtained, corresponding to a low Coulombic efficiency of ∼38%. Remarkably, after a few charge/discharge cycles, the electrode exhibited good cyclic stability, and Coulombic efficiency steadily remained above 98%. The electrode can remain at a gravimetric capacity of ∼489 mAh g–1 after 500 cycles. The volumetric capacity is ∼605 mAh cm–3 due to the low density of 1.3 g cm–3. Moreover, specific capacity of 380 mAh g–1 can be achieved after deep cycling at a high current density of 500 mA g–1. We also performed the repeated tests of charge/discharge process for five times at 100 mA g–1 (Figure S5). The profiles and capacity values after 500 cycles are similar to each other, suggesting good repeatability of the electrode. To make a comparison, we also measured the lithium storage of [Pb­(INO)2]2 (HINO = isonicotinic acid N-oxide) and [Pb­(CPINO)2] (HCPINO = N-(4-carboxyphenyl)­isonicotinamide 1-oxide), both of the ligands containing N-oxide and carboxylate functional groups at both terminals. As shown in Figure S6, the title as-prepared Pb-MOF exhibited the highest discharge specific capacity, which may be attributed to the large conjugated system and the rigid organic moiety.
elements.clean_text: c showed the cycling performance and Coulombic efficiency of the electrode. The initial charge and discharge capacities of 578 and 1522 mAh g-1 were obtained, corresponding to a low Coulombic efficiency of ~38%. Remarkably, after a few charge/discharge cycles, the electrode exhibited good cyclic stability, and Coulombic efficiency steadily remained above 98%. The electrode can remain at a gravimetric capacity of ~489 mAh g-1 after 500 cycles. The volumetric capacity is ~605 mAh cm-3 due to the low density of 1.3 g cm-3. Moreover, specific capacity of 380 mAh g-1 can be achieved after deep cycling at a high current density of 500 mA g-1. We also performed the repeated tests of charge/discharge process for five times at 100 mA g-1 (Figure S5). The profiles and capacity values after 500 cycles are similar to each other, suggesting good repeatability of the electrode. To make a comparison, we also measured the lithium storage of [Pb(INO)2]2 (HINO = isonicotinic acid N-oxide) and [Pb(CPINO)2] (HCPINO = N-(4-carboxyphenyl)isonicotinamide 1-oxide), both of the ligands containing N-oxide and carboxylate functional groups at both terminals. As shown in Figure S6, the title as-prepared Pb-MOF exhibited the highest discharge specific capacity, which may be attributed to the large conjugated system and the rigid organic moiety.

elements.content: In addition, a showed the remarkable high rate capability of the as-prepared electrode. High reversible capacities of 489, 442, 382, 301, and 268 mAh g–1 can be obtained as the current densities vary from 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 mA g–1, respectively. After the rate was decreased back to 0.1 A g–1, the discharge capacity could recover to the initial value, demonstrating good recyclability in a long cycling. Such a highly symmetric pattern could be attributed to the facile ion diffusion in the interconnected channels and robustness of the MOF structure.
elements.clean_text: In addition, a showed the remarkable high rate capability of the as-prepared electrode. High reversible capacities of 489, 442, 382, 301, and 268 mAh g-1 can be obtained as the current densities vary from 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 mA g-1, respectively. After the rate was decreased back to 0.1 A g-1, the discharge capacity could recover to the initial value, demonstrating good recyclability in a long cycling. Such a highly symmetric pattern could be attributed to the facile ion diffusion in the interconnected channels and robustness of the MOF structure.

elements.content: (a) Rate performance at different current densities. (b) Nyquist plots of the Pb-MOF electrode. The inset is the proposed equivalent circuit.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Rate performance at different current densities. (b) Nyquist plots of the Pb-MOF electrode. The inset is the proposed equivalent circuit.

elements.content: To gain further insight, the Nyquist plots of the Pb-MOF electrode before and after cycling were also investigated from 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz. Obviously, a depressed semicircle at the medium-high-frequency region and a straight line at an approximate 45° angle assigned to the Warburg impedance can be observed for both of the Nyquist plots (b). The intercept on the Z′-axis of the high-frequency is related to electrolyte resistance (R s), and the semicircle in middle-frequency region is associated with the charge-transfer resistance (R ct) between the electrolyte and electrode interface. In addition, C s represents the surface film capacitance. The fitting values are listed in Table S3. Obviously, the charge-transfer resistance for Pb-MOF electrode after the 500th cycle was smaller than that before the cycling, demonstrating the rapid electron transport in the process of lithium intercalation/deintercalation. This is consistent with the high Coulombic efficiency steadily after several initial cycles and the significant improvement in rate performance.
elements.clean_text: To gain further insight, the Nyquist plots of the Pb-MOF electrode before and after cycling were also investigated from 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz. Obviously, a depressed semicircle at the medium-high-frequency region and a straight line at an approximate 45° angle assigned to the Warburg impedance can be observed for both of the Nyquist plots (b). The intercept on the Z'-axis of the high-frequency is related to electrolyte resistance (R s), and the semicircle in middle-frequency region is associated with the charge-transfer resistance (R ct) between the electrolyte and electrode interface. In addition, C s represents the surface film capacitance. The fitting values are listed in Table S3. Obviously, the charge-transfer resistance for Pb-MOF electrode after the 500th cycle was smaller than that before the cycling, demonstrating the rapid electron transport in the process of lithium intercalation/deintercalation. This is consistent with the high Coulombic efficiency steadily after several initial cycles and the significant improvement in rate performance.

elements.content: depicts the performance comparison of Pb-MOF with those already reported in literature. The high discharge capacity of the Pb-MOF electrode could be attributed to the unique structure feature, which can provide more binding sites during the test of lithium storage. To further explore the possible mechanism for Li storage, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) before and after the fully discharged state was studied (Figure S7). The XPS spectrum of Pb 4f consists of two main peaks at ∼143.0 eV for Pb 4f 5/2 and ∼138.1 eV for 4f 7/2, corresponding to the Pb2+ state. No obvious difference was found, indicating that no conversion reaction occurred after full discharge. On the basic of DFT calculations, the N-oxide, carboxylate group, benzene ring, and pyridine ring in the Hocppy ligand can act as possible Li binding sites (). These binding sites may be applicable to explain the insertion/extraction mechanism during the test of lithium storage (), which was further confirmed by the appearance of peak in the IR spectra and the solid-state 13C NMR spectra of the Pb-MOF electrode before and after cycling (Figure S8 and S9). The theoretical capacity would be 506 mAh g–1 after considering that the organic moieties per formula unit could provide 12 potential binding sites for Li storage (each Li+ contributes ∼42.2 mAh g–1). To better understand the charge/discharge curve of the material, we attempted to find the global minimum structure at different Li ion intercalation stages based on the above Li binding energy analysis. The average voltages (V) for Li intercalation into Pb-MOF host structure were calculated by the following equation: V = − E ( Li x 2 MO 2 ) − E ( Li x 1 MO 2 ) − ( x 2 − x 1 ) E ( Li ) ( x 2 − x 1 ) e and specifically as V = − E { Li x 2 ( Pb − MOF ) } − E { Li x 1 ( Pb − MOF ) } − ( x 2 − x 1 ) E ( Li ) ( x 2 − x 1 ) e where E{Li x2(Pb-MOF)} and E{Li x1(Pb-MOF)} correspond to the energies of intercalated and initial systems, respectively. E(Li) is related to the energy that one Li atom corresponding to the potential of Li, and (x 2–x 1) refers to the number of the intercalated Li ions. Figure S10 illustrates the profiles of the calculated average voltages. Obviously, the theoretical voltage captured the trend of the experimental discharging curve. A wide voltage pseudoplateau at around 0.65 V is observed, which is close to the experimental discharge voltage (around 0.5 V), followed by a gradual decline. Indeed, most peak positions of the PXRD patterns before and after 500 charge/discharge cycles are similar to those of the as-prepared sample, indicating that the framework and structure stability are maintained after removal of the guest molecules and the cycles (Figure S2). The intensity differences and the slight changes of small peaks at 14 and 20° 2θ could be ascribed to the preferred orientation effect of the crystalline samples. Obviously, SEM images in Figure S11 reveal that no disintegration or pulverization of the electrode can be observed before and after the cycling process, which explains the good cycling stability.

elements.content: In summary, a porous 3D Pb-based MOF was successfully prepared under solvothermal conditions. The as-prepared robust framework facilitates the transport of Li+ ions. When the MOF is used as an anode electrode material, a specific capacity of 489 mAh g–1 can be obtained after 500 cycles. In this study, the organic moiety seems to play a critical role for the storage mechanism. Moreover, this electrode exhibits stable cycling behavior and good rate performance.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, a porous 3D Pb-based MOF was successfully prepared under solvothermal conditions. The as-prepared robust framework facilitates the transport of Li+ ions. When the MOF is used as an anode electrode material, a specific capacity of 489 mAh g-1 can be obtained after 500 cycles. In this study, the organic moiety seems to play a critical role for the storage mechanism. Moreover, this electrode exhibits stable cycling behavior and good rate performance.

cln_elements.content: A mixture containing 4,4′-Hocppy (11 mg, 0.05 mmol), Pb­(NO3)2 (33 mg, 0.1 mmol), 2 mL of H2O, and 2 mL of dimethylformamide was placed in a glass reaction bottle and heated at 80 °C for 3 d. Then, the system was cooled naturally to obtain colorless rod-like crystals. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3564 (s), 3412 (s), 1637 (m), 1614 (s), 1558 (w), 1382 (w), 1122 (m), 617 (s), 476 (m). Elemental analyses calcd (%) for C24H30N2O13Pb: C, 37.84; H, 3.94; N, 3.67. Found C, 37.81; H, 3.96; N, 3.69.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Pb(4,4'-ocppy)2]⋅7H2O

A mixture containing 4,4'-Hocppy (11 mg, 0.05 mmol), Pb(NO3)2 (33 mg, 0.1 mmol), 2 mL of H2O, and 2 mL of dimethylformamide was placed in a glass reaction bottle and heated at 80 °C for 3 d. Then, the system was cooled naturally to obtain colorless rod-like crystals. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3564 (s), 3412 (s), 1637 (m), 1614 (s), 1558 (w), 1382 (w), 1122 (m), 617 (s), 476 (m). Elemental analyses calcd (%) for C24H30N2O13Pb: C, 37.84; H, 3.94; N, 3.67. Found C, 37.81; H, 3.96; N, 3.69.

cln_elements.content:
A microporous Pb-based metal–organic framework (MOF) [Pb­(4,4′-ocppy)2]·7H2O (Pb-MOF) has been constructed from 4-(4-carboxyphenyl)­pyridine N-oxide and Pb­(NO3)2. Structural analysis reveals that the Pb-MOF possesses three-dimensional framework with a one-dimensional rhombic channel. When tested as a lithium-ion battery anode, a reversible lithium storage capacity of 489 mAh g–1 was maintained after 500 cycles at 100 mA g–1 as well as excellent cycling stability. The superior electrochemical performance may be derived from the sustenance of the Pb-MOF framework and compositional features of the organic moiety.

Results and DiscussionStructure Description

The as-synthesized Pb-MOF crystal was formulated as [Pb­(4,4′-ocppy)2]·7H2O through single crystal analysis, which was further determined by TGA and EA. Structural analysis reveals that the title Pb-MOF crystallizes in monoclinic C2/c space group and represents a porous framework. Each asymmetric unit contains two ligands, one Pb2+ cation, along with seven lattice water molecules. The Pb ion is seven-coordinated, surrounded by four O atoms from N-oxide and the remaining three oxygen atoms from two carboxylic groups (a). Four oxygen atoms adopting a hemidirected structural arrangement are sitting on one side of the Pb ion, indicative of the existence of an active lone electron pair. Moreover, three weak Pb···O bonds shown as dashed lines (Pb–O3a = 2.804(2), Pb–O4 = 2.819(2), Pb–O6a = 2.864(9) Å) are also presented in a. Two adjacent Pb ions are connected together by two μ2-O atoms of N-oxide, leading to the formation of a 1D Pb–O chain (b). Such coordination interactions generate a 3D framework structure with a size of 9.8 × 9.8 Å2 (c). Through use of the PLATON/SOLV program, a solvent accessible volume was estimated to 40.0% (1265.4 Å3 of the 3165.4 Å3 unit cell volume) after omitting the lattice water molecules.

To examine the thermal stabilities of Pb-MOF, PXRD and TGA were applied. PXRD pattern of the as-made product was quite identical to its corresponding simulated results, indicating a pure phase of the bulky crystalline samples (Figure S2). TGA curves in Figure S3 show that the first weight loss between 30 and 150 °C corresponded to the removal of 7 lattice H2O (observed, 16.97%; calcd, 16.54%). Above 300 °C, organic ligands start to decompose, giving PbO as a final product (observed, 29.93%; calcd, 29.30%). To obtain the dehydrated phase, the as-made Pb-MOF was heated at 120 °C for 2 h to remove the solvent molecules. No obvious weight loss of was detected below 300 °C. Subsequently, framework decomposition led to the formation of PbO product (observed, 35.14%; calcd, 35.11%). According to the N2 sorption experiments, the pore characteristics exhibited typical type-I curve with microstructure along with the surface area of 725 m2 g–1 and pore volume of 0.47 cm3 g–1 (Figure S4). Moreover, the Pb-MOF exhibited electrical conductivity of 7.2 × 10–2 S m–1. This relatively high conductivity value and robust framework could provide a charge transport pathway and offer more active sites for embedding Li+.

c showed the cycling performance and Coulombic efficiency of the electrode. The initial charge and discharge capacities of 578 and 1522 mAh g–1 were obtained, corresponding to a low Coulombic efficiency of ∼38%. Remarkably, after a few charge/discharge cycles, the electrode exhibited good cyclic stability, and Coulombic efficiency steadily remained above 98%. The electrode can remain at a gravimetric capacity of ∼489 mAh g–1 after 500 cycles. The volumetric capacity is ∼605 mAh cm–3 due to the low density of 1.3 g cm–3. Moreover, specific capacity of 380 mAh g–1 can be achieved after deep cycling at a high current density of 500 mA g–1. We also performed the repeated tests of charge/discharge process for five times at 100 mA g–1 (Figure S5). The profiles and capacity values after 500 cycles are similar to each other, suggesting good repeatability of the electrode. To make a comparison, we also measured the lithium storage of [Pb­(INO)2]2 (HINO = isonicotinic acid N-oxide) and [Pb­(CPINO)2] (HCPINO = N-(4-carboxyphenyl)­isonicotinamide 1-oxide), both of the ligands containing N-oxide and carboxylate functional groups at both terminals. As shown in Figure S6, the title as-prepared Pb-MOF exhibited the highest discharge specific capacity, which may be attributed to the large conjugated system and the rigid organic moiety.

Conclusion

In summary, a porous 3D Pb-based MOF was successfully prepared under solvothermal conditions. The as-prepared robust framework facilitates the transport of Li+ ions. When the MOF is used as an anode electrode material, a specific capacity of 489 mAh g–1 can be obtained after 500 cycles. In this study, the organic moiety seems to play a critical role for the storage mechanism. Moreover, this electrode exhibits stable cycling behavior and good rate performance.
cln_elements.clean_text:
A microporous Pb-based metal-organic framework (MOF) [Pb(4,4'-ocppy)2]⋅7H2O (Pb-MOF) has been constructed from 4-(4-carboxyphenyl)pyridine N-oxide and Pb(NO3)2. Structural analysis reveals that the Pb-MOF possesses three-dimensional framework with a one-dimensional rhombic channel. When tested as a lithium-ion battery anode, a reversible lithium storage capacity of 489 mAh g-1 was maintained after 500 cycles at 100 mA g-1 as well as excellent cycling stability. The superior electrochemical performance may be derived from the sustenance of the Pb-MOF framework and compositional features of the organic moiety.

Results and Discussion

Structure Description

The as-synthesized Pb-MOF crystal was formulated as [Pb(4,4'-ocppy)2]⋅7H2O through single crystal analysis, which was further determined by TGA and EA. Structural analysis reveals that the title Pb-MOF crystallizes in monoclinic C2/c space group and represents a porous framework. Each asymmetric unit contains two ligands, one Pb2+ cation, along with seven lattice water molecules. The Pb ion is seven-coordinated, surrounded by four O atoms from N-oxide and the remaining three oxygen atoms from two carboxylic groups (a). Four oxygen atoms adopting a hemidirected structural arrangement are sitting on one side of the Pb ion, indicative of the existence of an active lone electron pair. Moreover, three weak Pb⋅⋅⋅O bonds shown as dashed lines (Pb-O3a = 2.804(2), Pb-O4 = 2.819(2), Pb-O6a = 2.864(9) Å) are also presented in a. Two adjacent Pb ions are connected together by two μ2-O atoms of N-oxide, leading to the formation of a 1D Pb-O chain (b). Such coordination interactions generate a 3D framework structure with a size of 9.8 × 9.8 Å2 (c). Through use of the PLATON/SOLV program, a solvent accessible volume was estimated to 40.0% (1265.4 Å3 of the 3165.4 Å3 unit cell volume) after omitting the lattice water molecules.

To examine the thermal stabilities of Pb-MOF, PXRD and TGA were applied. PXRD pattern of the as-made product was quite identical to its corresponding simulated results, indicating a pure phase of the bulky crystalline samples (Figure S2). TGA curves in Figure S3 show that the first weight loss between 30 and 150 °C corresponded to the removal of 7 lattice H2O (observed, 16.97%; calcd, 16.54%). Above 300 °C, organic ligands start to decompose, giving PbO as a final product (observed, 29.93%; calcd, 29.30%). To obtain the dehydrated phase, the as-made Pb-MOF was heated at 120 °C for 2 h to remove the solvent molecules. No obvious weight loss of was detected below 300 °C. Subsequently, framework decomposition led to the formation of PbO product (observed, 35.14%; calcd, 35.11%). According to the N2 sorption experiments, the pore characteristics exhibited typical type-I curve with microstructure along with the surface area of 725 m2 g-1 and pore volume of 0.47 cm3 g-1 (Figure S4). Moreover, the Pb-MOF exhibited electrical conductivity of 7.2 × 10-2 S m-1. This relatively high conductivity value and robust framework could provide a charge transport pathway and offer more active sites for embedding Li+.

 c showed the cycling performance and Coulombic efficiency of the electrode. The initial charge and discharge capacities of 578 and 1522 mAh g-1 were obtained, corresponding to a low Coulombic efficiency of ~38%. Remarkably, after a few charge/discharge cycles, the electrode exhibited good cyclic stability, and Coulombic efficiency steadily remained above 98%. The electrode can remain at a gravimetric capacity of ~489 mAh g-1 after 500 cycles. The volumetric capacity is ~605 mAh cm-3 due to the low density of 1.3 g cm-3. Moreover, specific capacity of 380 mAh g-1 can be achieved after deep cycling at a high current density of 500 mA g-1. We also performed the repeated tests of charge/discharge process for five times at 100 mA g-1 (Figure S5). The profiles and capacity values after 500 cycles are similar to each other, suggesting good repeatability of the electrode. To make a comparison, we also measured the lithium storage of [Pb(INO)2]2 (HINO = isonicotinic acid N-oxide) and [Pb(CPINO)2] (HCPINO = N-(4-carboxyphenyl)isonicotinamide 1-oxide), both of the ligands containing N-oxide and carboxylate functional groups at both terminals. As shown in Figure S6, the title as-prepared Pb-MOF exhibited the highest discharge specific capacity, which may be attributed to the large conjugated system and the rigid organic moiety.

Conclusion

In summary, a porous 3D Pb-based MOF was successfully prepared under solvothermal conditions. The as-prepared robust framework facilitates the transport of Li+ ions. When the MOF is used as an anode electrode material, a specific capacity of 489 mAh g-1 can be obtained after 500 cycles. In this study, the organic moiety seems to play a critical role for the storage mechanism. Moreover, this electrode exhibits stable cycling behavior and good rate performance.

metadata.title:
Lead-Based
Metal–Organic Framework with Stable Lithium Anodic Performance
